text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to hot thai kitchen 
if you follow me on Facebook you notice that

my new year resolution for 2015 is to eat more 
vegetables so today I am making a dish that is

full of vegetables that it's also very popular 
it is pad Priew Waan or sweet and sour stir-fry Pad

means to stir-fry priew is sour and wan is sweet so 
I'm doing mine with tofu but you can use chicken

or whatever protein you like or leave the protein 
out altogether that's fine as well and my version

I'd like to say is not sweet and thick with lots 
of sauces actually really light and feels really

healthy so let's get started as I always do with 
my surprise I like to mix the sauce together first

so this sauce I've got some white vinegar which 
is going to be the sour part of this and then

for the salty I've got some oyster sauce some 
what is that soy sauce that's right soy sauce

and the sweet part I'm using brown sugar now you 
can use regular sugar or even palm sugar but I

actually like sort of the molasses the richness 
that brown sugar has for this dish and I am also

using si Racha or Thai hot sauce which is this 
guy and this is the original serie cha which is

what the rooster sauce the famous rooster sriracha 
is sort of based on if you don't have the Thai one

that's okay you can use the rooster Brown as 
well it will be a little spicier and a little

less sweet so you may have to adjust the sauce 
just a little bit also sesame oil I said just a

little bit of sesame oil to give it a little extra 
something something yeah just a little that's good

okay that's it that's the sauce super super easy 
you've got sweet I got sour I got salty perfect

now I'm using tofu when I stir-fry with tofu I 
always use at least medium firm because of it

gets too soft and if I'm using medium for me also 
like to fry it there are three benefits to frying

tofu for stir-fry one it gives a really nice 
golden color and it looks pretty too it creates

a rough surface so it holds onto sauce better and 
three it prevents them from crumbling because the

outside gets a little bit chewier if you don't 
want to fry tofu that's totally fine just make

sure you use firm or extra firm tofu and again 
you can use chicken you can use shrimp you can

use whatever you like vegetables I love this dish 
because I can throw any kind of vegetables I want

in it but the important to vegetables that I need 
is tomatoes and pineapple they're going to help

add that sweet-and-sour quality to the stir-fry 
with tomatoes you can use large one and and slice

them into wedges I just happen to have grape 
tomatoes on hand so that's what I'm using and

a slice of and have the little ones actually keep 
them whole and just make a little slit because I

don't want cherry tomatoes that's hot and steaming 
and then you bite into it burst in your mouth and

burns your mouth bad news I've got some onion 
some bell peppers whatever color you like some

cucumber which is also really really commonly 
used in Thailand as in a stir-fry I know people

don't usually eat cooked cucumber in North America 
but it's really good and we do put it in soups and

stir fries but I'm using the mini cucumber at the 
store it was labeled Japanese cucumber I've seen

it labeled Persian cucumber I find them a little 
crunchy err and they're easier to handle and I

don't know I just prefer these to the big ones 
what else got pineapple asparagus you don't have

to it's kind of a your your canvas you can throw 
whatever vegetables in here go time just a little

bit of oil in here and as with most stir-fries in 
Thailand I'm going to start with chopped garlic

okay come my garlic it's starting to turn brown if 
you're using meat you want to go in with your meat

first and then your vegetables but because I'm 
not using any meat all the veggies go in now I

know you're thinking whoa all your vegetables 
in at once yes that's the beauty of this dish

and I know the tomatoes don't take long to cook 
and they're going to mush and become a part of

the sauce and that's exactly what I want that's 
why I want the tomatoes to go in at the same time

as everything else so it has time to sort of 
disintegrate and sweeten the sauce in goes the

sauce and now I'm just going to cook this until 
the vegetables are done to my liking which is you

know tender but still got a little bit of crunch 
look like a party in the lock doesn't it this is

why I love making the fish there's so much fun 
to see all the colors there we go I think I am

there and if you're not sure you can just give 
give it a paste and go from there I'm going to

throw in my tofu at the last second because it's 
already cooked and I just need it to sort of mix

mingle and get coated with the sauce yes I like 
house tomatoes are getting stuff I'm going to

turn it off and then go in with my final greenery 
some green onions and some cashews just to give it

some nuttiness which i think is really important 
when you've got something this light and sour

and you know that nuttiness really balance with 
everything else give it a quick toss and it's

plating time always serve this with some jasmine 
rice ask Thai people we always eat all stir fries

with rice put a little bit more cashews on here 
I saved some especially if you're serving it to

other people so they can really see oh yeah 
shoes all right eating time I am so hungry

the reason why I love using medium firm tofu 
is because once you bite through the chewy

exterior you get to the inside and it's soft 
and silky and it just sort of melts in your

mouth mmm it's a great balancer of all the 
crunchy stuff and what I really love about

this particular style of sweet and sour said 
it's so light it doesn't have that rich thick

heavy sauce that this actually feels really 
healthy and I feel really good eating this

so I hope you give this a try and oh the recipe 
is on Hawkeye kitchen comm and if you enjoy the

show please click to subscribe and I'll see 
you next time for your next delicious timing
